subnotes.content: The series has been retained in its original order as received from Teachers College, Columbia University. The series is organized chronologically and by record type.

The series, which spans the years 1937-1990, is divided into five subseries:

(a) Correspondence (1937-1958)

(b) Administrative Files (1938-1955)
Includes annual reports, staff information, financial reports, and questionnaires.

(c) Administrative Files (1956-1990)
Includes history, correspondence, proposals, questionnaires, and codebook.

(d) Bibliographies and Publication Lists (1939-1954; 1972-1981)

(e) Publications (1939-1990)

(f) Collateral Projects (1943-1954)
Includes studies of Grant Store managers, Boy Scouts, and naval aviation cadets.
See Series 5a, Special Formats (Scrapbooks and Photographs), box 283, folder 3582.

The series documents the Foundation's first and longest-running grant, the "Grant Study of Adult Development," (also known as the "Harvard Grant Study" or the "Harvard Longitudinal Study"). The study was conducted at Harvard University and supported by the Foundation from 1938-1947, and again from 1957-1977. Dr. Arlie V. Bock was the first director of the project. George Vaillant, M.D., of Harvard University, joined the project staff in 1966 and published the latest findings of this study in December 2001. The study, conducted under several generations of researchers, has followed some of the original subjects for more than 50 years. 

The Grant Study was a turning point in the use of interdisciplinary research, combining knowledge from the fields of medicine, psychiatry, psychology, anthropology, and social services. An interdisciplinary approach has been characteristic of much of the research that the Foundation has funded ever since.
